metadata.title: Knee Pain  Unspecified Site – Conservative Management
synonyms: nonspecific knee pain  nonspecific, conservative management
anatomical location body part affected: Knee/tibiofemoral joint, patellofemoral joint, intraarticular and extraarticular structures around the knee
description: Numerous etiological factors and conditions may cause knee pain, including trauma, sudden exercise overload, training errors/overuse, systemic disease, biomechanical irritation, and inflammatory conditions, such as osteoarthritis (OA)
The attending physician may have diagnosed obvious causes such as acute fracture, stress fracture, soft tissue damage, and neurovascular compromise, as well as infection and tumors in medical cases

The prescription to treat knee pain will likely specify the site of injury and a diagnosis, if imaging and laboratory tests were performed, or if there is a history of deformity or related medical problem
A history of recent direct or indirect trauma will usually disclose the mechanism of injury
Common knee conditions that impair weight-bearing  include muscle or tendon strain, ligament sprain, meniscal tear, bursitis, fascial enthesitis, patellar maltracking, and articular cartilage damage
Typical causes of knee pain include OA, patellofemoral pain syndrome (PFPS), and meniscal, tendon, and ligament injuries(27)

Conservative management of knee pain involves protection, rest, icing, compression, and elevation (PRICE), as well as patient education, activity modification, and therapeutic exercise. Exercise-based  therapy is the foundation of treatment for OA and PFPS.(27) In a survey of patient preferences for management of chronic knee pain, physical therapy was the most popular(1)
See the Clinical Review  on specific knee condition and/or surgery if it was performed

M25.base: other joint disorders, not elsewhere classified

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement have been identified for common knee pain
presentation signs and symptoms: Knee pain (usually, but not always unilateral) – acute or chronic stage, site unspecified
Patient recalls feeling or hearing pop at time of contact injury
Grinding, clicking, or popping during bending of knee
Patient complains of knee ‘locking’ or ‘giving way’
Patient complains of pain when ascending/descending stairs, squatting, jumping, or turning activities
Swelling either immediately after injury or overnight. A ‘fluid wave’ on either side of patella
Limited active or passive range of motion
Ligamentous laxity upon testing Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Attempt to minimize patient apprehension and muscle guarding during examination of the knee joint
The physical exam should include assessment of the hip, knee, and foot
Assure maximum protection in cases of knee instability
Consider postponing the exam in cases with unresolved inflammation, infection or healing of soft tissue, or severe hematoma

causes: Direct trauma to knee (e.g., blunt blow, motor vehicle accident)
Sudden excessive torque, high-impact  force, or pressure on knee (e.g., sprain/strain from simple fall or jumping)

Activity-related  trauma in contact or noncontact sports–The mechanism of knee ligament or meniscus injury often involves sudden deceleration and rotation/twisting of kneewith the foot planted–Additional varus or valgus forces with knee hyperextension may produce associated intraarticular damage

Activity-related  overuse (acute unaccustomed physical activity or repeated microstress)–In a systematic review, knee was most common site of lower extremity injuries in runners(4)–PFPS and patellar tendinopathy are the most common diagnosis in running-related  knee pain(3)
Age-related  (OA, degenerative conditions, apophysitis in the young)
Referred pain from hip or back
Vascular (popliteal artery aneurysm, deep vein thrombosis)
pathogenesis: In the absence of a specific diagnosis on referral, the pathogenesis of the pain may not be understood. However, treatmentdecisions can be made according to the history, signs, and symptoms present upon physical examination

Patient may recall mechanism of injury(5,6,22)–If swelling after injury-Immediate – indicates hemarthrosis from fracture or cruciate ligament tear-Few hours – indicates intraarticular lesion, for example, meniscus tear–Noise at time of injury-Pop – indicates anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) tear-Crunch – indicates medial meniscal tear-Tearing sensation – indicates collateral ligament injury–Swelling, redness, warmth – signs of inflammation (consider infection)–Does knee ever lock (i.e., cannot fully extend due to physical block)?-Usually due to torn meniscus – refer within 24 hours–Catching or clicking – indicates loose body, torn meniscus, degenerative joint disease–Snapping – indicates inflamed synovial plica–Does knee give way?-Occasional giving way is common with patellofemoral pain or symptomatic degenerative joint disease-True giving way – subluxing patella, loose body due to previous trauma or osteochondritis dissecans, torn meniscus,chronic ligamentous instability–Grating sensation – patellofemoral pain, degenerative joint disease–Pain when bending and walking down stairs–Pain with prolonged sitting may indicate patellar tracking issues–How does problem limit daily activities?–Exercise-related  knee pain often increases with the same physical activity that caused it and then decreases with rest–Are other joints involved?

The location of knee pain is often associated with certain conditions(3,7,22)–Anterior knee pain that involves patella indicates the following:-PFPS-Chondromalacia patella-Patellar tendinitis (jumper’s knee)-Quadriceps tendinitis-Patellar subluxation/dislocation-Bursitis (prepatellar or suprapatellar)-Patellar apophysitis (Sinding-Larsen-Johansson syndrome)-Patellofemoral articular cartilage defect–Anterior knee pain that does not involve patella indicates the following:-ACL tear-Tibiofemoral OA-Tibialapophysitis (Osgood-Schlatter  disease)-Synovial chondromatosis-Osteochondritis dissecans-Tibial eminence fracture–Medial knee pain indicates the following:-Medial (tibial) collateral ligament sprain-Medial meniscal tear (may also produce posterior pain)-Anserine tendinopathy (pes anserine strain)-Medial tibiofemoral articular cartilage defect-Medial plica syndrome–Lateral knee pain indicates the following-Lateral (fibular) ligament sprain-Lateral meniscal tear (may also produce posterior pain)-Iliotibial band friction syndrome-Lateral tibiofemoral articular cartilage defect–Posterior knee pain indicates the following:-Popliteal (Baker’s) cyst-Posterior cruciate ligament (PCL) tear-Distal hamstrings strain-Proximal gastrocnemius strain-Popliteus strain/tendinitis–Nonspecific knee pain indicates the following-Knee OA-Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)-Femur/tibia fracture-Cellulitis-Pseudogout (calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease)-Tumor/cyst around knee-Referred pain from hip (slipped capital femoral epiphysis, Legg-Calve-Perthes  disease)-Neurovascular compromise

A comprehensive exam of the knee includes:(5)–lower extremity alignment–effusion–joint line tenderness–ROM–muscle tone/strength–apprehension test (patellar instability)–patellar grind test (patellar dysfunction/maltracking)–Lachman test (ACL integrity)–anterior drawer test (ACL integrity)–posterior drawer test (PCL integrity)–posterior sag sign (PCL integrity)–pivot shift test (anterolateral knee instability/ACL tear)–valgus/varus stress test (medial collateral ligament [MCL]/lateral collateral ligament [LCL] integrity)–McMurray test (meniscal tear)–Ege’s test (meniscal tear)–Ober’s test (iliotibial band tightness)–Homans’ test (for DVT)–Thomas test
risk factors: History of previous injuries in runners(4,8)

High-risk  sports involving cutting, jumping, and/or deceleration–Noncontact (e.g., skateboarding, skiing, soccer, basketball, handball, volleyball, running)–Contact (e.g., football, rugby, hockey, wrestling)
High weekly training distance in male runners(4,8)
Reduced quadriceps and hamstring flexibility may contribute to patellar tendinitis in athletes(4)

overall contraindications precautions: Unexplained inability to bear weight, with signs of fracture or infection
Severe swelling of knee in a patient with apparent febrile illness
Assess degree of injury/stage of healing and treat appropriately
Obtain parental or guardian consent in pediatric cases
Confirm physician orders on weight-bearing  status, ROM restrictions, and exercise therapy
Evaluate for safety limitations in knee joint ROM, weight-bearing,  and comorbidity/illness that may affect therapeutic planning
Significant neurological deficits are not usually associated with knee pain. Notify referring physician immediately if sensory or motor deficits are found in the involved limb
Notify referring physician immediately on discovery of evidence suggestive of DVT or thrombophlebitis
Refer immediately to emergency care if evidence of ischemia or paralysis is present in the affected limb
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Attempt to minimize patient apprehension and muscle guarding during examination of the knee joint
The physical exam should include assessment of the hip, knee, and foot
Assure maximum protection in cases of knee instability
Consider postponing the exam in cases with unresolved inflammation, infection or healing of soft tissue, or severe hematoma

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: See Causes , Pathogenesis , & Risk Factors , above

course of treatment.medical management: Conservative treatment usually consists of protection (compression sleeve or brace), activity modification, patient education, and pain medication, as needed for reduction of inflammation
surgical management: Surgical management:  See Clinical Review on specific knee condition if surgery was performed
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications have been prescribed; are they being taken? NSAIDs for acute knee sprain or strain(3,5) Ibuprofen 200-800  mg t.i.d. Naproxen 375-500  mg b.i.d. Indomethacin 25-50  mg t.i.d. Acetaminophen safe and effective in doses up to 3 g/day for analgesia in OA(3,10) Intraarticular corticosteroid injection may provide short-term  pain relief in knee OA(3,11)
diagnostic tests completed: X-rays  help in diagnosis of OA, osteochondral lesions, and PFPS(3)
MRI is ‘gold standard’ for soft tissue imaging(3)
CT scan to rule out occult knee fracture(3)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions, and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: List factors that aggravate or ease the patient’s symptoms
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 0-10 scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night, if anyDocument the need for supplemental oxygen or need for ventilator support
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could indicate physician referral (e.g., marked increase in swelling) Barriers to learning Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ If yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, orthopedic disorders, etc.
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in gym classes, sports, or other recreational activities? Is the patient in school? Does the patient work? If so, what repetitive motions is he/she required to perform that require knee movement?
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs that patient is required to ascend/descend daily, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives (caregivers, etc.). Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home, work, or school and whether any modifications appear necessary

relevant tests and measures.general: ›Relevant tests and measures (while tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting):
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Measure height and weight; assess body mass index (BMI) for obesity. Assess for edema with knee circumference measurements. Evaluate for leg length discrepancy
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Evaluate need for assistive ambulatory device (e.g., cane, crutches, possibly a walker or wheelchair in older persons) and modify prescription, as appropriate. Assess fit and ensure safe operation of assistive devices. Assess appropriateness of knee brace, if applicable, and ability to correctly don/doff
relevant tests and measures.balance: (Assess for nonsymmetrical weight-bearing  in bipedal standing.) If not stable, assess stability in standing using assistive device. When appropriate for weight-bearing  status, assess in single-leg  stand and for dynamic balance with perturbations
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess for palpable tibial and pedal pulses. Evaluate for DVT. Assess peripheral pulses in cases with –Localized calf tenderness and erythema are present –Calf circumference is more than 3 cm greater than that of uninvolved limb –Superficial veins in calf are prominent –Homans' sign (pain in calf on passive ankle dorsiflexion) is presentScan entire lower extremity for intact neurological functionAssess ability in transfers, steps, and gait while staying within physician’s guidelines. In evaluation for return to sport, assess ability to perform single-leg  squat without hip internal rotation, jog, walk sideways, run, hop, and jump and land with controlled knee valgus
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess gait when ambulatory assistive device is discontinued and patient is full weight-bearing  status; observe for limp, stiff knee pattern, and decreased stance on affected limb. If ambulatory, observe for altered or antalgic gait pattern in walking (and running, when appropriate, in runners). 6MWT can be used to assess endurance and dynamic gait index (DGI) if safety during gait is compromised Assess for normal dynamic tracking of patella in active ROM within postoperative guidelines. Postpone ligament stress testing until physician’s orders permit
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess using manual muscle testing (MMT) –After patient is full weight-bearing  and ambulatory, isometric strength testing is usually safe –Manually test static strength at the hip, knee (in 40° flexion), and ankle. Expect quadriceps weakness, which is due in part to inhibition and reduced voluntary muscle control in knee pain. Assess for quadriceps extensor lag (deficit in active knee extension) –Compare quadriceps/hamstrings strength ratio to uninvolved side –Assess for activation of the vastus medialis obliquus at terminal knee extension and involuntary coactivation of hamstrings during knee extension
observation inspection palpation includi: Inspect for swelling compared to unaffected knee

Assess skin condition for lesions and infection (warm, swollen, and red) •Palpation:  Assess for localized tenderness around knee and calf, quadriceps atrophy localized to tendon attachments (quadriceps, distal hamstrings, proximal gastrocnemius) and the presence of a popliteal cyst
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess lower extremity alignment in standing and knee alignment in walking when patient can ambulate safely on treadmill. Assess ankle alignment in subtalar neutral
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess active-assisted/active  and passive ROM of the knee joint, as well as the hip and ankle joints. Assess for knee flexion contracture that may contribute to extensor lag. Assess entire LE for functional ROM
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Assure that Achilles tendon reflex is intact
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Assess the following –Touch and thermal (warm and cold) sensation around knee –Sensation and movement in foot/toes –Proprioception at knee joint
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: See Causes , Pathogenesis , & Risk Factors , above, for list of knee tests to consider

other: Patients with knee pain are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall prevention strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall prevention strategies

Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Electrotherapy  contraindications (in some cases, when approved by the treating physician , electrotherapy may be used under some of the circumstances listed below when benefits outweigh the perceived risk)(12)

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Knee pain; reduced knee ROM and strength; deficits in ADLs and functional mobility (e.g., gait, dynamic posture, balance, transfers)
assessment plan of care.rule out: Concomitant lower extremity pain not localized to knee
prognosis: Prognostic studies on outcomes in nonspecific knee pain are lacking. The time frame for resolution of pain and recovery of knee function will likely depend on the type of injury, the extent of soft tissue damage (whether there is permanent damage), joint stability, presence of infection, coexisting conditions, and patient motivation to comply with prescribed exercises.(3) Minor acute injuries should heal completely in two to eight weeks

Researchers of a multicenter, prospective study conducted in the Netherlands found that higher BMI, lower level of education, more comorbidities, higher activity limitation scores, and joint space tenderness were more often associated with patients with more pain at presentation and a faster pain progression over five years than patients with a mild pain progression(28) –Based on a study of 705 patients with early symptomatic knee OA
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Orthopedist for specific “red flags” and persisting inability to achieve full ROM or normal strength; occupational therapist for deficits in ADLs; pain management specialist for unremitting pain; weight-loss  clinic for obese patients; aquatic therapist for pool exercise. Acupuncture may help to reduce knee pain in patients who do not exercise(13)
other considerations: Older adults –Poor performance on a short physical performance battery (i.e., time for five repeated chair stands, walking speed over four meters, and standing balance) was a useful measure of functional capacity in a population of 1,006 older persons (mean age 75 years) with chronic knee pain and perceived disability in ADLs(14) –Location of knee pain in older adults may determine disability(29) -Based on a study conducted in the United States of 2959 painful knees as part of the Osteoarthritis Initiative -A combined pain pattern of both tibiofemoral and patellofemoral pain was associated with greater odds of reporting pain, symptoms, sports, or recreational activity limitations and lower knee-related  quality of life compared with either tibiofemoral or patellofemoral pain alone  –Lifestyle modifications, such as physical activity for 150 min/week, maintaining a healthy weight/diet can decrease knee pain associated with OA(26) –Authors of a systematic review and narrative synthesis concluded that long-term  (3-30  months) exercise is safe for most older adults with knee pain(30) –Older patients with chronic knee pain were found to have more work productivity if their work involved at least 30% sitting time and higher levels of support from co-workers(32) -Based on a questionnaire study conducted in Australia of 129 workers –Adding an internet-based  intervention with home exercise and automated pain-coping  skills training (PCST) to educational materials improved pain and function in patients > 50 years old with chronic knee pain(33) -Based on an RCT conducted in Australia of 148 community-dwelling  adults -PCST consisted of eight weekly interactive, automated modules, which included progressive relaxation, activity-rest cycling, and distraction techniques, as well as participation in seven Skype sessions with physiotherapists over 12 weeks. Control group only received educational materials -Outcomes were pain during walking and physical function (WOMAC) at three months

Obesity –A program of quadriceps strengthening and dietary advice was associated with reduced knee pain and improved ADLs function in overweight persons compared to controls(15) –The current recommendations from the American Academy of Orthopedic Surgeons for the treatment of knee OA focus on exercise-based  therapies and targeted weight loss(27)
treatment summary: There is good consensus that exercise-based  therapy is the first-line treatment for knee OA and PFPS, two of the most common causes of knee pain treated with conservative management(27)

There is good quality evidence that active rehabilitation (stretching, strengthening, exercise programs) is just as effective as arthroscopy at reducing pain and improving function in patients with nontraumatic degenerative medial meniscal tears without mechanical symptoms(27)
Protection, rest, icing, compression, and elevation (PRICE) for pain, and edema management(3)

Manual therapy –OA knee pain decreased and ADLs improved in 26 patients (mean age 56.5 years) treated with the Macquarie Injury Management Group Protocol (three sessions per week, two weeks) compared to controls(16) –Similarly, six sessions of transverse friction massage to the lateral retinaculum increased knee flexion and improved stair climbing in anterior knee pain(17) –Authors of an RCT comparing manual therapy to supervised exercise therapy demonstrated that those receiving manual therapy had significant improvements with pain and functional outcomes(24) -RCT study from India involving 74 patients with anterior knee pain (age range of 18-65)  randomized into manual therapy + exercise (experimental group) or supervised exercise group (control group). Sessions lasted for 15-20  minutes for a total of six treatment sessions over a two-week  period -Control group performed supervised self-exercises consisting of stretches to the hamstring, rectus femoris, and iliotibial band for 30 second holds twice per session. Strengthening exercises consisted of exercises for the knee flexors and knee extensors -Experimental group received transverse friction massages to the lateral retinaculum as per the Cyriax model with the knee in full extension and knee in full flexion. Patients also performed supervised exercise programs and performed exercises similar to the control group
Therapeutic ROM and strengthening exercises(18) –Main objective for patients suffering from anterior knee pain is to strengthen the vastus medialis(25)
Functional exercises to improve posture, balance, and gait, as indicated(19)

Knee braces can be used for stabilizing traumatic knee ligament and tendon tears, but have uncertain evidence in the treatment of chronic knee pain and should never replace physical therapy(27)  . desired outcomes outcome measures: Resolution of pain and swelling–V AS, circumferential measurement
Functional ROM (> 120° flexion); full knee extension–Knee goniometry
Lower-extremity  strength comparable to unaffected side–MMT
Normal symmetrical gait–Gait assessment, 6MWT(20), TUG(20), DGI
Normal balance–Berg Balance Test, 1-leg  hop test
Appropriate physical fitness and clearance for return to regular activities/sport with physician’s approval–International Knee Documentation Committee Subjective Knee Form(21)

maintenance or prevention: Continue knee rehabilitation exercises after discharge, including progressive quadriceps strengthening and dynamic balance training

Researchers in Finland conducted a life course study of men in the military from age 18 through age 50 and found that higher BMI at age 20 was predictive of knee pain and functional limitations (walking difficulties, limping) later in life, and that severe obesity that develops during a lifetime increases the risk of knee pain by 80% and functional limitations by more than 90%(31) Based on a study of 1913 men who participated in the Health 2000 Study (follow-up) The authors suggested that prevention of obesity early in life may prevent the development of knee pain and functional disability later in life
